Try

. Experience - pressure of short field season - get experience beforehand if you can - potential masters/PhD students - current PhD students

. Before you go: https://ecopostblog.wordpress.com/fieldwork-and-travel-advice/ - documents - passport - communication with family - make links in country - get to know your team if you can and ask for advice - insurance, medical, travel and gadget - “There might be group email lists that you can join in advance, for example, for finding accommodation or learning about social activities.” - ethical approval (it can take months to get!) – “several photocopies of my passport, flight itineraries, phone # for embassy/consulate/place I’m staying, and tons of maps. massive redundancy is good in these things. “ - email copies to yourself too - passport photos

. Training - First aid - navigation with a compass and map reading (don’t rely on fancy GPS!) - make sure you know how to use your equipment and kit - fitness

  • arrange for someone to meet you at the airport (or at least find out how much a taxi should cost, have numbers of some good taxi drivers)

. Action plan and budget - plans might not work out, but planning is still essential

. Field logistics Accommodation “Where to stay? Choosing to stay with a particular family or NGO will have implications for how you are seen by others. There’s unlikely to be a perfect answer. You will also need to balance practicalities, for example, a house with some facilities.” Transport Catering Equipment and stores (see below) Fuel requirements Water supplies Communication Navigation Reconnaissance visit (see Appendix 2)
